questions.text: A 25 -year-old man flips over a vehicle, and he lands on his leg. On physical examination, there is intense pain on palpation over the right shin, but there is no shortening of the limb. The overlying skin is intact. A radiograph shows the right tibial and fibula midshaft fracture into multiple bone fragments. Which of the following terms best describes these fractures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Comminuted When the bone is splintered into fragments , the fracture is comminuted, and will likely require orthopedic appliances to align fragments for healing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. A compound fracture penetrates the skin. An open fracture, also called a compound fracture , is a fracture in which there is an open wound or break in the skin near the site of the broken bone. Most often, this wound is caused by a fragment of bone breaking through the skin at the moment of the injury. Option: C. Displaced fractures have nonaligned bone, and some deformity may result. A displaced fracture means the pieces of your bone moved so much that a gap formed around the fracture when your bone broke Option: D. An incomplete, or greenstick, fracture occurs when the bone cracks and bends but does not completely break; when the bone does break into separate pieces, the condition is called a complete fracture The bone remains contiguous with an incomplete fracture that does not extend completely across the shaft of the bone.

questions.text: Exsanguination is one of the first steps before the application of a tourniquet preoperatively. All the following are contraindications for exsanguination except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Underlying fracture Presence of underlying infection or tumor is an absolute contraindication for exsanguination since that can cause dissemination. Fatal pulmonary embolism may result if exsanguination is done over underlying deep vein thrombosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Fatal pulmonary embolism may result if exsanguination is done over underlying deep vein thrombosis Option: C. Presence of underlying infection is an absolute contraindication for exsanguination since that can cause dissemination Option: D. Presence of tumor is an absolute contraindication for exsanguination since that can cause dissemination

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a Salter-Harris type IV fracture of the distal femur from a football tackle. The fracture has 4 mm of displacement and 20 degrees of angulation in the sagittal plane. Because of his young age, you know the bone has excellent potential for remodeling. The best treatment option would include?

options.label: C
options.text: Open reduction and internal fixation with distal femoral locking plate

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and internal fixation of both components with plates and/or screw fixation

questions.correct_answer: D. Open reduction and internal fixation of both components with plates and/or screw fixation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Open reduction and internal fixation of both components with plates and/or screw fixation Intra Articular fractures in children are treated much as those in adults. Attention must be paid to the physical region, but anatomic reduction and stability are required, achieved with cc screws or plates.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Since it is intra-articular and involves physics , the anatomical reduction is required which is difficult with a long leg cast Option: B. difficult to hold reduction, so not the best choice. Option: C. Because children have thick periosteum and faster , more consistent healing, large rigid implants are not typically necessary (and would likely compromise the physis), so C is not the best answer

questions.text: A polytrauma patient with a wound around 0.6 cm over the lower femur with a fracture of the femur arrives in the emergency room. What is the grade of injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade 1 Type I: clean wound less than 1 cm length

Highyeild:

Gustilo Anderson classification for open fractures. Types Type I: clean wound less than 1 cm length Type II: wound > 1 cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, or avulsion Type III: wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, communication, contamination, or segmental fractures Type III A: adequate periosteal coverage there Type IIIB: significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap Type IIIC: open fracture with a vascular injury that requires vascular repair

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Type II: wound > 1 cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, avulsion Option: C. Type III: wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, communication, contamination or segmental fractures Type III A: adequate periosteal coverage there Option: D. Type IIIC: open fracture with a vascular injury that requires vascular repair

questions.text: A child of 7 years sustained an injury to his ankle region. X Rays show a fracture with a metaphyseal fragment along the epiphyseal line. Which type of salter harris injury is this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 2 Salter-Harris classification: Physical injury Option: A. Type I: fracture line is entirely within physics causing epiphyseal slip

Highyeild:

Type I: fracture line is entirely within physics causing epiphyseal slip Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis (Thurston Holland’s fragment) Type III: fracture line extends from physis into epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Type IV: fracture line extends across the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis Type v: crush injury of physics with initially normal X rays

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis ( Thurston Holland’s fragment) Option: C. Type III: fracture line extends from physis into epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Option: D. Type IV: fracture line extends across the epiphysis, physics, and metaphysis

questions.text: The classification used for Epiphyseal injury is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Salter-Harris classification Salter harris classification: epiphyseal injury

Highyeild:

Type I: fracture line is entirely within physics causing epiphyseal slip Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis (Thurston Holland’s fragment) Type III: fracture line extends from physis into epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Type IV: fracture line extends across the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis Type v: crush injury of physics with initially normal X rays

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Bado classification is used in Monteggia's fracture classification. Option: B. Arlet and Ficat used in AVN of femoral head classification. Option: D. Gustilo Anderson used in open fractures classification.

questions.text: All are true regarding prophylactic antibiotics except?

options.label: A
options.text: Given from less than 1 hour before until 24 hours after procedure

options.label: B
options.text: Repeated if preceding time is more than 6 hours (longer than the half-life of an antibiotic selected)

options.label: C
options.text: Repeated if blood loss more than 1000 mL

options.label: D
options.text: Doubled if the patient weighs more than 80 kg (>176 lb)

questions.correct_answer: B. Repeated if preceding time is more than 6 hours (longer than the half-life of an antibiotic selected)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repeated if preceding time is more than 6 hours (longer than the half-life of an antibiotic selected) Antibiotic is repeated after 4 hours and not six hours.

Highyeild:

Prophylactic antibiotics: Given from less than 1 hour before until 24 hours after procedure Repeated if preceding time is more than 4 hours (longer than the half-life of an antibiotic selected) Repeated if blood loss more than 1000 mL Doubled if the patient weighs more than 80 kg (>176 lb) Antibiotic is repeated after 4 hours and not six hours.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. True statement Option: C. True statement Option: D.- True statement

questions.text: Thurston Holland fragment is seen in which type of salter Harris injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type II Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis ( Thurston Holland's fragment)

Highyeild:

Salter-Harris classification : Physical injury Type I: fracture line is entirely within physics causing epiphyseal slip Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis (Thurston Holland's fragment) Type III: fracture line extends from physis into epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Type IV: fracture line extends across the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis Type v: crush injury of physics with initially normal X rays

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Not in type 1 Option: C. Not in type 3 Option: D. Not in type 4

questions.text: The worst prognosis is of which type of salter Harris injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type V Type V has the worst prognosis, as there is no visible fracture but the growth plate is crushed and results in arrested growth.

Highyeild:

Salter-Harris classification : Physical injury Type I: fracture line is entirely within physics causing epiphyseal slip Type II: fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis (Thurston Holland's fragment) Type III: fracture line extends from physics into epiphysis causing epiphyseal split Type IV: fracture line extends across the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis Type v: crush injury of physics with initially normal X rays

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Type v not I Option: C. Type v not I Option: D. Type v not I

questions.text: The basic principle of plating is that?

options.label: A
options.text: Plate should be applied to the compression side of the bone

options.label: B
options.text: Compound fractures are initially fixed with a plate

options.label: C
options.text: Length of the plate should be six times the width of the fracture

options.label: D
options.text: Plate should be applied to the tension side of the bone

questions.correct_answer: D. Plate should be applied to the tension side of the bone
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Plate should be applied to the tension side of the bone Plate should be applied to the tension side of the bone-correct statement.

Highyeild:

Neutralization plates do not apply compression but add some extra stability to a fracture that has been primarily compressed and stabilized by a lag screw. The plate may be applied subperiosteally by a formal exposure of the fracture or osteotomy, or extraperiosteally in the submuscular plane to span the site. In addition to improving contact between the bone ends, compression through the plate can be utilized as a part of the tension-band concept. Curved long bones have a compression side and tension side when axially loaded; Plate application on the tension side will convert the loading forces that attempt to separate the fracture ends into compressive ones and thereby maintain bone contact.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Plate applied on the tension side of a fracture and not on the compression side. Option: B. Compound fractures are initially fixed with external fixation and not plate . Option: C. Incorrect statement.

questions.text: Patients presenting with transverse fracture of right Tibia and fibula with a wound of approximately 0.8 cm over the fracture site. Which grade of Gustilo Anderson injury is this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type I Type I: clean wound less than 1cm length

Highyeild:

Type I: clean wound less than 1cm length Type II: wound more than 1 cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, avulsion Type III: wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, communication, contamination or segmental fractures Type III A: adequate periosteal coverage there Type IIIB: significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap Type IIIC: open fracture with a vascular injury that requires vascular repair

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Type II : wound more than 1 cm in length without extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap, avulsion Option: C. Type III : wound associated with extensive soft tissue damage, communication, contamination or segmental fractures. Type III A: adeQuate periosteal coverage is present. Option :D. Type IIIB : significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap Gustilo Anderson classification for open fractures.

questions.text: A patient post-RTA is brought in casualty with quadriparesis. What is the first step of management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate surgical fixation of cervical spine

options.label: B
options.text: Accompany the patient to radiology room

questions.correct_answer: C. Cervical spine stabilization in emergency
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cervical spine stabilization in emergency Cervical spine stabilization in an emergency with a cervical collar. According to ATLS, sequence is Airway with cervical protection Breathing Circulation Disability or neurological status Exposure and environment- removing clothes, keep warm

Highyeild:

According to ATLS, sequence is Airway with cervical protection Breathing Circulation Disability or neurological status Exposure and environment- removing clothes, keep warm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. not immediate surgical fixation, as stabilization and evaluation of the patient are necessary first. Option: B. Incorrect statement Option: D. Incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman injured her finger while playing volleyball. She presented to the emergency department with the deformity seen below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mallet Finger Mallet's finger is a characteristic flexion deformity of the distal phalanx seen secondary to the avulsion of the extensor tendon from the base of the distal phalanx.

Highyeild:

Deformities due to fractures Deformity Fracture ● Gun stock deformity (cubitus varus) ● Cubitus valgus ● Dinner fork deformity . ● Mallet finger ● Coxa vara ● Genu valgum ● Varus-valgus at ankle Supracondylar fracture of the humerus Fracture of lateral condyle of humerus Colles' fracture Avulsion of the extensor tendon from base of distal phalanx Inter-trochanteric fracture Condylar fractures of tibia (e.g., bumper fracture) Ankle injuries

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Boutonnière deformity is the result of an injury to the tendons that straightens the middle joint of your finger. The result is that the middle joint of the injured finger will not straighten, while the fingertip bends back. Option: C. Swan-neck deformity is a bending in (flexion) of the base of the finger, a straightening out (extension) of the middle joint, and a bending in (flexion) of the outermost joint. Option: D. Ulnar drift is usually seen in rheumatoid hands.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman slipped in her bathroom. History reveals she fell on the floor awkwardly on an outstretched hand. After getting up she developed pain and swelling in her left wrist. The left wrist is deformed as shown below. What is this deformity called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dinner fork deformity Dinner fork deformity is a classic deformity seen in Colles fracture which is a fracture of the distal end of radius.

Highyeild:

Deformities due to fractures Deformity Fracture ● Gun stock deformity (cubitus varus) ● Cubitus valgus ● Dinner fork deformity . ● Mallet finger ● Coxa vara ● Genu valgum ● Varus-valgus at ankle Supracondylar fracture of the humerus Fracture of lateral condyle of humerus Colles' fracture Avulsion of the extensor tendon from base of distal phalanx Inter-trochanteric fracture Condylar fractures of tibia (e.g., bumper fracture) Ankle injuries

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. A decrease in the normal valgus alignment to neutral at the elbow is called a Cubitus rectus. Option: C. A Smith's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius where the distal fragment is angulated volar. This can result in a permanent "garden-spade deformity". Option: D. Coxa vara is a deformity of the hip, whereby the angle between the head and the shaft of the femur is reduced to less than 120 degrees. This results in the leg being shortened and the development of a limp. It may be congenital and is commonly caused by injury

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presented with a deformity of her knees. The parents give a history of the deformity increasing since childhood. Now the deformity has reached such an extent that she is not able to walk properly and perform her day-to-day activities. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Genu Valgum Genu valgum, commonly called "knock-knee" , is a condition in which the knees angle in and touch each other when the legs are straightened. Individuals with severe valgus deformities are typically unable to touch their feet together while simultaneously straightening their legs.

Highyeild:

Deformities due to fractures Deformity Fracture ● Gun stock deformity (cubitus varus) ● Cubitus valgus ● Dinner fork deformity . ● Mallet finger ● Coxa vara ● Genu valgum ● Varus-valgus at ankle Supracondylar fracture of the humerus Fracture of lateral condyle of humerus Colles' fracture Avulsion of the extensor tendon from base of distal phalanx Inter-trochanteric fracture Condylar fractures of tibia (e.g., bumper fracture) Ankle injuries

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Genu varum (also called bow-leggedness, bandiness, bandy-leg, and tibia vara) is a varus deformity marked by (outward) bowing at the knee, which means that the lower leg is angled inward (medially) about the thigh's axis, giving the limb overall the appearance of an archer's bow. Usually, medial angulation of both lower limb bones (femur and tibia) is involved. Option: B. Congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), often known as 'club-foot', is a common but little-studied developmental disorder of the lower limb. It is defined as fixation of the foot in adduction, in supination, and in varus, i.e. inclined inwards, axially rotated outwards, and pointing downwards Option: D. Stiff knee presents with decreased range of motion of the knee and may even present as an ankylosed knee.
